attributes.action: Tax rebate for those who worked during the pandemic in their place of work
attributes.background: I want the Government to arrange a tax rebate for those who had to go into work during the pandemic; those of us who were not furloughed and could not work from home due to the nature of our jobs.
attributes.additional_details: I think everyone who went into work during the pandemic should be rewarded for continuing to work at their place of work and helping keep the country functioning. Our taxes helped pay for the Government furlough scheme so why can't we have some back?

attributes.action: Repeal restrictions on protest in the Police Crime Sentencing and Courts Act
attributes.background: All restrictions on protest introduced in the Act, such as noise limits and application of the rules to one person, should be removed, in line with the House of Lords' ruling
attributes.additional_details: The House of Lords had already vetoed the restrictions on protest due to their draconian nature, however they have been reintroduced and passed anyways. This underhand  introduction is wholly inappropriate. Previous legislation regarding protests were sufficient to allow for protest while respecting the need for public safety.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petition:

Remove new protest provisions from Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/610277

The Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill is not yet an Act of Parliament. The Bill is currently at consideration of amendments stage. You can find out more about this stage of a Bill's passage through Parliament here:
https://www.parliament.uk/about/how/laws/passage-bill/commons/coms-consideration-of-amendments/

The House of Commons considered the Lords Amendments to this Bill on Monday 28 February 2022 and have returned the Bill to the Lords disagreeing with their amendments.

You can follow updates on the Bill's progress here:
https://bills.parliament.uk/bills/2839

attributes.action: Save Wethersfield Airfield
attributes.background: The Government is reneging on commitments in the Environment Act to stop the decline of wildlife by proposing to develop two mega-prisons on the site of the old Wethersfield airfield, which has become an important space for nature near Braintree, Essex.
attributes.additional_details: Some 74 species of birds, many Red-listed, nest nearby and the area comprises 75,000 trees and shrubs. The site also includes ancient woodland, as well as Great Crested Newts and rare orchids. Red-listed birds on the site include European Turtle Dove, Northern Lapwing and Grey Partridge.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the prospect of new prisons being built around RAF Wethersfield, but we're not sure if you want the Government to commit to not building these prisons here, or take some other action or actions regarding this site.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Make the use of Digital Health Passports illegal
attributes.background: Prohibit the use of ‘NHS Covid Pass’ or medical certification in any UK setting. Health passports and digital ID are a major infringement on privacy, data protection and personal liberties.
attributes.additional_details: The use of any form of digital medical or health certification is a gross invasion of privacy and the first step towards a “papers please” checkpoint society. It is also in direct conflict with core British values of openness and inclusion. Such certification is highly coercive in nature as it raises the prospect of citizens having no choice but to undergo medical procedures and/or constant testing in order to avoid being excluded from society.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/596004

attributes.action: Ban selling disposable barbecues without a stand, to prevent grass damage
attributes.background: The Government should make it illegal to sell barbecues without a permanently attached stand for them to be used on. This could be a fold out stand or legs. This would ensure manufacturers stop producing disposable barbecues without such stands.
attributes.additional_details: Parks, natural green spaces and nature reserves are being damaged by people using disposable barbecues with little to no thought of the grass being burnt and long term damage caused.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Protect the right to freedom of speech in the home for all British peoples.
attributes.background: The government appears to be considering extending hate speech laws to the privacy of the home,  This is contrary to the principles of freedom of speech and thought that have been hard won rights in the UK.  Parliament must reject any such change.
attributes.additional_details: The British population has developed its democratic conventions over many centuries.  They have fought hard, suffered and died to end totalitarian and repressive rule by religion or state. The right to freedom of speech is sacrosanct and is now in great peril.  The British must have the right to express themselves freely and safely in the privacy of their own homes, a location naturally regarded as sacrosanct. This proposal breaches all the best traditions of freedom.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

There are no current Government proposals to alter the law on the use of "threatening, abusive or insulting" language inside private homes. There is currently a consultation by the Law Commission, who are independent of Government, on changes to the law:

https://www.lawcom.gov.uk/project/hate-crime/
	
You may wish to consider responding to the consultation.

attributes.action: Allow outdoor tennis during the Covid lockdown
attributes.background: The government should allow outside tennis to continue during lockdown, including doubles and organised sessions.
attributes.additional_details:
Outdoor tennis is naturally socially distanced and represents limited risk of transmission of Covid. The risks of transmission can be further reduced by hand washing, closing pavillions/bars at tennic clubs and players using their own balls when serving. 

The health, including mental health benefits, from playing tennis outweigh any risks from it, so the government should allow outdoor tennis to continue during lockdown.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

Allow indoor/outdoor tennis courts to operate under strict distancing protocols: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557428

Exempt outdoor tennis from closure due to COVID-19: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557658

attributes.action: Allow  Green Homes Grant to be used with non-TrustMark tradesmen.
attributes.background: Allow the public to use other reputable tradesman that are not TrustMark approved. Just because a tradesman are not TrustMark approved, doesn't mean they are not reputable. The govt could use lots of other bodies to measure the quality of a tradesmans workmanship.
attributes.additional_details:
There are not enough TrustMark approved tradesman to service the amount of people wanting to utilise the Green Homes Grant. Therefore it is impossible for the public to utilise the Green Homes Grant. 

It is imperative the public can have access to grants, and unfortunately due to the nature of the approved tradesman, the public are unable to utilise the grant.

attributes.action: Tanning Salons should be specifically identified as 'non-contact' Beauty Salons.
attributes.background: Tanning Salons are asked by councils to close their businesses during the current Covid outbreak, simply as a result of them being unfairly classed as 'within' the Beauty Salons grouping of businesses. Tanning Salons should be correctly re-classed within this group, as non-contact and Covid-Safe.
attributes.additional_details: Tanning Salons are entirely non-contact by the nature of the business. Enhanced ventilation systems are already in place. Tanning on sunbeds takes place within an enclosed room, and these sunbeds/rooms are each individually ventilated. Replenishment with entirely clean air is much more frequent than in most other types of businesses. Tanning Salons are a very popular activity that presents a uniquely Covid-Safe leisure pursuit, without adding any additional risk. This is a legislative anomaly.

rejection.details: Since you started your petition, the Government has confirmed that tanning salons are able to reopen.

attributes.action: Change the law regarding late term abortion due to potential disabilities.
attributes.background: I want the Government to amend the 1967 Abortion act so no baby may be aborted simply because it may have disabilities of physical or mental nature.
attributes.additional_details:
Allowing disability as a reason for abortion implies that disabled people, or the lives of disabled people, are less worthwhile than the lives of "normal" people.

We wouldn't permit abortion on the grounds of race or gender so why disability? It's fundamentally Eugenics and wrong.

If we are truly an equal and open society then this law must change.

rejection.details:
Abortion after 23 weeks ("late term abortion) is permitted only if there’s evidence of a fatal foetal abnormality or a significant risk to the mother's life if she continues with the pregnancy.

We're not sure what change to that law you want to make.

attributes.action: Close UK airports for two months every year
attributes.background: In the light of the clear benefits to the environment revealed by the current coronavirus lockdown to prohibit air travel to and from the UK for two months every year.
attributes.additional_details: To give nature a break from human activity which is damaging to the environment; to acknowledge the negative impact air travel has on the environment; to encourage other ways of global contact; to begin promoting clean air; to recognise that humans are part of nature and not separate from it; to create a cleaner place for all species to co-exist; to recognise the damage already inflicted upon the earth by human activity and to set an example to encourage ongoing support for environmental change.

attributes.action: Plant a memorial forest/area of nature for the victims of the Corona Virus.
attributes.background: The Govt should purchase a significant area of land within the UK and to plant a tree for every global victim of the virus and for every key worker who has kept the rest of us safe. Family members of victims can name trees in memory of their loved ones, but it is a forest for the people.
attributes.additional_details: The CV tragedy has had a catastrophic impact around the world, and the fact that the virus has spread to most countries around the globe, reinforces how we are a global community. It is important that victims and key workers are never forgotten and the hope is that their legacies will contribute to a global commitment to plant other such areas in other countries and help to reduce carbon levels in the atmosphere. In doing so, their legacies will help to save the lives of millions in the future.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/314071

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you find out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
 
Find out more: https://committees.parliament.uk/work/192/the-governments-response-to-coronavirus/

attributes.action: Amend Sexual Offenders Act 2003 with regard to "breach of peace" in community.
attributes.background: Provide a gateway in existing legislation where a person subject to restrictions within the Sexual Offenders Act 2003 has the burden to prove that [he] does not pose a threat to any person accused of potential Breach of the Peace (BOP), which directly implicates [him], ie; the person accused of BOP.
attributes.additional_details: I was asked by someone, recently arrested for a confrontation between him and a person who was subject to the Sex Offenders Act (register), what can he do?  I was asked can I do anything to evict the perpetrator from the area.  I gave him the honest answer, not much!.  Notwithstanding the above, I later thought that this seems unfair given the nature of the arrest.  The burden of reassurance to the community should lie with the person on the Sex Offenders Register, that [he] is no longer a risk.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action. 
	
We're not exactly sure what action you'd like the Government or Parliament to take. For example, we're not sure if you want a person subject to restrictions within the Sexual Offenders Act 2003 to be relocated if they are found guilty of breaching the peace in their local area, or if you'd like something different. 
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Overgrown tree issues becoming dangerous
attributes.background: We need these tree’s in our street to be cut back and maintained as much as possible as it’s becoming such a health and dangerous issue to the community and no one seems to be listening or helping.
attributes.additional_details:
Cars are been damaged 
People are slipping and falling on wet leaves, massive branches falling from tress 
Houses suffering from no natural sunlight 
Electricity bills sky high as lights are needing to be on during the day.
All because of overgrown mass amount of trees and bushes.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Maintenance of local roads, including any trees on these roads, are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: A Referendum on the Green Revolution
attributes.background:
I want parliamentary debates on the best way to achieve our Green goals.
I want transparency and most of all I want the people to choose for themselves. For the people by the people
attributes.additional_details: Set up debates on Green energy, on electrification, on nature reserves and on Green jobs to look after our environment.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about public input to proposals to achieve environmental goals, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Hold a referendum on whether to keep the 2050 net zero target: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/599602

attributes.action: Medical Tribunals for Mental Health Patients soley under the care of their GP
attributes.background: So many people, who already experience of mental distress, are complaining of being not listened to by their GPs. GPs are NOT specialists in mental health and often fail to understand or care about the more outwardly subtle nature of mental health conditions which can, at the same time, be severe.
attributes.additional_details: The nature of a GP-patient relationship is one where the GP has absolute power and the patient has none. This may make some sense in the case of an infected absess, but very often can cause even more mental distress to a patient who suffers from a psychiatric condition. I propose that, if there is a disagreement between a GP and a mental health patient who has no other care, then the issue should be taken to a tribunal made up at least in part by mental health professionals.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about patient rights to challenge decisions by their GPs in certain circumstances, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. It's not clear what you mean by someone being "soley under the care of their GP", or what you want the role of the tribunals you propose to be.

NHS patients can already complain about any aspect of NHS care, treatment or service. You can find out more about this here: https://www.nhs.uk/using-the-nhs/about-the-nhs/how-to-complain-to-the-nhs/

If what you want is for patients to be given a legal right to appeal decisions made by their GP, and for these to be considered by an independent tribunal, we should be able to accept a petition requesting this.

attributes.action: Revoke the neonicotinoid insecticide authorisation and ban its future use
attributes.background: This authorisation is a knee-jerk reaction that doesn't see the bigger picture and might cause immense harm. Almost three quarters or our crops are pollinated by bees yet we have possibly lost a third of our bees in the last ten years. Neonicotinoids ultimately kill off bees and other pollinators.
attributes.additional_details:
The Govt is going back on its word on "maintaining environmental standards and international obligations from 1 January 2021." They claimed its 25 Year Environment Plan would see "the first generation to leave the natural environment in a better state than it inherited it." 
Save our future. Stick to your word.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Debate UNICEF donating to UK councils to make such donations unnecessary.
attributes.background: Provide sufficient funding to local councils to enable all children have a proper diet so that charities such as UNICEF don't see the need to make donations to those local councils.
attributes.additional_details: It is embarrassing for the nation for large charities to see elements of society as so poor that they need the same support as countries suffering from natural or politically caused famine.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign these petitions which call for similar actions:
 
End child food poverty – no child should be going hungry: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554276

Take action to address the rising levels of child poverty: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552744

attributes.action: Outdoor tennis courts to remain open when lockdown restrictions tighten on 5 Nov
attributes.background: We are asking the Government to ensure that outdoor tennis can continue between people from the same household, or between two individuals from different households - for example a tennis coach and player - when the national lockdown measures come into force in England on Thursday 5th November.
attributes.additional_details:
Tennis is extremely beneficial to physical & mental well-being. Played on outdoor courts, it naturally lends itself to social distancing - played in a covid-secure way in the open air. 

The Lawn Tennis Association (LTA) supports outdoor tennis courts staying open for two individuals from different households. They describe tennis as a ‘socially distanced sport with the net as the natural barrier’. 

It would be counterproductive to shut down a sport that can be played safely and responsibly.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

Allow indoor/outdoor tennis courts to operate under strict distancing protocols: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557428

Exempt outdoor tennis from closure due to COVID-19: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/557658

attributes.action: Stop plans to build large row of flats on Beehive Lane communal area.
attributes.background: The operational director of housing informing us that they will build new flats opposite beehive court on beehive lane. The communal land is our garden and is where all of us come together as a community. We are signing against this and do not wish for new flats to be built opposite our homes.
attributes.additional_details:
1 It is a Fire and safety hazard with two properties being too close to eachother
2 We spend time as a community on this land 
3 Our children play on this small area
4 Very little space here even less space will cause a crowded neighbourhood
5 Noise and building work disruption  
6 Reducing greenery and nature
7 Other areas in Redbridge have larger space to build on
8 It will increase crime and antisocial behaviour in area
9 We need investment in the current buildings that have existed for years

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. Local planning issues are the responsibility of your local council.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Stop the government from introducing calorie labelling on menus in the UK
attributes.background:
Stop the introduction of calorie labelling at chains. This would be incredibly harmful to people struggling with eating disorders and encourage disordered behaviour. 
Fixation on calorie intake is a way in which disordered thinking manifests and leads to obsessive behaviours regardless of weight.
attributes.additional_details:
Between 1.25 and 3.4 million people in the UK are diagnosed with an eating disorder. This is likely an underestimate because the nature of the illness sees a high number of cases undetected and undiagnosed.
Not only will this affect those struggling as well as those recovered/in recovery, it could likely lead to normalisation of calorie intake obsession, precipitating the development of eating disorders even in healthy and overweight adults who have lost weight in order to improve their health.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/332940

attributes.action: Make catcalling and gender-based street harassment illegal in the UK
attributes.background:
The Anti-Harassment Club defines street harassment as any unwanted behaviour of a sexual nature, whether implicit or explicit, forced on a stranger in a public place without their consent. 
 
UK law must change. Street harassment must be recognised as the pervasive violation of human rights it is.
attributes.additional_details:
YouGov found that 64% of women of all ages have experienced unwanted sexual harassment in public places. This increases to 85% of girls aged 18-24 with 45% of those experiencing unwanted sexual touching. Only 11% of women said anyone had intervened though 81% said they wished someone had (2016). 
 
The police should be intervening. In recent years France, Belgium, Portugal, Peru and New Zealand have all implemented new laws to criminalise street harassment. The UK is falling behind.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/323460

attributes.action: Implement a robust nationwide strategy to reduce littering
attributes.background:
Enforcement of the financial penalties in Environmental Protection Act 1990 through paid wardens and local volunteers

Community service in the form of litter picking for those caught littering more than once

Signage in hotspots showing the environmental impact of littering and penalties
attributes.additional_details:
The UK has an increasing problem with of littering. It is believed that 62% of people drop litter.

The cost to the government is approximately £1billion (40,000 nurses or 434,000 school meals)

Litter has a devastating impact on nature, killing millions of animals every year and leads to vast pollution, 

Research has shown that litter leads to tensions within communities and impact on the mental health of residents

The UK need an effective long term plan to solve this problem.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/324488

attributes.action: Discipline police who support BLM protesters. The army should restore order.
attributes.background:
The current protests inspired by Black Lives Matter have been violent and have caused damage to important national monuments.

We should therefore sack or discipline any police officer participating in or expressing sympathy with these protests.

The army should step in to restore order.
attributes.additional_details:
They recent protests in the UK are clear breaches of lockdown laws and are unauthorised protests by their very nature and the police as the enforcers of law should not be permitting them to take place  let alone participating in or expressing sympathy with them.

It's clear the police have failed. Officers have showed sympathy or failed to enforce the law as it stands. 

Discipline officers demonstrating sympathy with the protests and send in the army to restore order where the police fail.

rejection.details:
Maintaining public order is the responsibility of the police, not the military. The Government has said that the Ministry of Defence is working with a range of partners across Government, including the National Police Chiefs Council and the Home Office, to understand how it can best support the Government’s response to the outbreak. It would be an operational decision for the police whether to request assistance.

You can find out more here: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/covid-support-force-the-mods-contribution-to-the-coronavirus-response.

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you find out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.

Find out more: https://committees.parliament.uk/work/192/the-governments-response-to-coronavirus/

attributes.action: Ban the sale & use of pesticides in the domestic domain to save bee populations!
attributes.background: I am turning 27 years old May 29th 2020 & every year of my life for as long as I can remember approx 23yrs, when spring comes so does our fight against nature. Curious I've never intervened in natures process & any boom such as ants, quickly retreat out from my living area without poison methods.
attributes.additional_details:
Firstly I want for this to be acknowledged as a potential public health & safety issue due to inadequate training for safe use in our domestic domain and for reading ages of adult populations to be considered in the scrutiny of this issue.

Secondly, like tobacco, for all pesticide branded packaging made plain.

Ultimately I want those in power to ban the sale of domestic pesticide products and promote the education of alternate holistic methods to better improve public knowledge and safety.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/315431

attributes.action: keep and continue with environmental benefits that have arisen from lockdown.
attributes.background: We want our government to publicly research and clearly document the environmental changes that have occurred in and around the uk since global lockdown has been instigated. Then if benefits are proven to be so, act DECISIVELY on its findings to continue the environmental improvements.
attributes.additional_details: I as many of us have been noticing more and more over recent decades how the weather,climate the seasons even, are all undeniably colder,hotter,more unpredictable than I remember. I have noticed over the last month and a half how how the sky is as blue as it used to be, the birds are more numerous and vociferous, even columns of insects are rising in the evenings seem larger. It is obvious even to my 7 and 9 year old children that nature comes back strong when given even a slight free hand.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions that make a clear request for an action the Government or House of Commons is responsible for.

We understand that you want any environmental benefits that have been achieved due to the Covid-19 outbreak to be preserved for the future, but it's not clear exactly what you want the Government to review or how you want it to act on the finding.

We have published the following related petition which you might like to sign:

Study impact of home working on health & the environment and act on the results: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/317466

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you find out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
 
Find out more: https://committees.parliament.uk/work/192/the-governments-response-to-coronavirus/

attributes.action: Include plants & planting as 'essential items and activity' during C19 lock-down
attributes.background: Urgently review the 'essential items and activities' to include plants, agriculture and horticulture. This is a time-sensitive issue... planting and nature will not wait!
attributes.additional_details:
Mitigate:
• the potentially devastating impact of C19 lockdown rules n the agriculture and horticulture industries
• long-term implications of not allowing people to tend their allotments mean potential fruit/veg shortages
• the impact on insect and wildlife [with reduced pollination] long-term impacts
• impact on mental health if people can't 'do something' for nature in these terrible times – homes need life in plant form too populated with butterflies/bees [other insects], etc.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. Agriculture has been permitted, including the use allotments. There is no essential items list, but there are limited retailers who are able to operate for visitors, however since you started your petition garden centres have been able to reopen. 
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Make it mandatory to build houses on all brownfield sites 1st before greenfield.
attributes.background: The government must make it mandatory to build new homes on brownfield sites instead of destroying areas of natural land to preserve the wildlife which inhabit them and the beauty of these natural areas, making use of sites which have previously been developed but now unused.
attributes.additional_details: Although there is a need for housing, more areas of local natural space are being destroyed to meet the increasing need to build more homes, leading to fewer natural spaces within and around local communities for nature to thrive and for people to benefit from. Distinction between council districts are diminishing in places due to the development of new housing. No new land should be destroyed until all brownfield sites have been utilised to their potential. Prioritising preservation of nature.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you're concerned about development of greenfield sites, but it's not clear if you want a total ban on development of greenfield land, or just restrictions on when development of greenfield land can be approved.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do. If you want new restrictions on when development of greenfield land can be approved, rather than an outright ban, it would need to be clear what restrictions you want to be imposed.

attributes.action: Abolish tuition fees
attributes.background: The government and Parliament need to debate on the issue of paying over £9,000 a year for tuition fees. The asymmetrical nature of devolution has meant that Scottish residents can attend university for free, whereas can’t in England. The cost of the fees needs to be either cut on lowered
attributes.additional_details: Especially because of the Covid Pandemic; the incumbent students as well as prospective students aren’t and won’t have the same university experience as previous cohorts. England has by far the most expensive tuition fees in the world and while higher education is still accessible to the masses, people from disadvantaged backgrounds are somewhat deterred by the amount that has to be paid. The government thus has to rethink the advantages of charging an extortionate amount of money for tuition

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/604197

attributes.action: Influence the Faroe Islands Government to ban the killing of whales and dolphins
attributes.background:
UK Government to work internationally to pressure the Faroe Islands Government to ban the killing of whales and dolphins.

Use diplomatic means to make it clear we oppose this practice and apply pressure to the Faroe Islands government to consider that not all traditions fit in the modern world.
attributes.additional_details: The recent cull of 1428 white sided dolphins represents a loss of about 1 in every 150 of this species globally, a huge impact. The practice demonstrates a complete disregard for nature which is linked to behaviours that threaten our long term existence. By not actively opposing this, other efforts to protect the environment made by businesses and individuals feel futile by comparison. The continued practice also may legitimise other’s negative behaviours toward our environment.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/597171

attributes.action: Abolish the Gillick Competence legislation.
attributes.background: The Gillick Competence Test was introduced to allow children under the age of 16 to consent to being prescribed contraceptions. However, it can be used for children to consent to other medication or medical interventions without their parents´ knowledge or consent; that is dangerous and wrong.
attributes.additional_details: Access to contraception for minors, if ministers wish it, requires specific legislation for it only. Contraception is taken to voluntarily to alter a natural bodily function; medicines, vaccines and other treatments or interventions prevent involuntary illness from a malfunction of the body or protect it from foreign elements e.g. bacteria, viruses, irritants etc. Minors may not understand issues surrounding treatment, such as need for, risk, being in trial phases etc.; parents must be involved.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about children under 16 being able to consent to certain medical treatment, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. The Gillick competence test applies as a result of case law, and is not set out in legislation.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to require parental consent for all medical treatment for children aged under 16, if that's what you want to happen.

attributes.action: Invest in the environmental infrastructure of the England.
attributes.background: It is time we start to address the decline of our planet by beginning at home, investing in the future wellbeing of our country through mass environmental projects, aimed at increasing the amount of green space (parks, national grounds, wildlands), and the reforesting of the Fells across England.
attributes.additional_details:
I hope you see the value of nature, if not, none of my words can convince you; however, if you do, then see that this is the moral and just thing to do. The amount of job creation would be substantial.

We can easily set an example, here in England to the rest of the world on what they too should be doing; Investing, not just to make more money, but to ensure future generations can thrive. Nature, has given us all we have. Can we please give back. You can do good, and gain the publics love.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see more done to increase green space in the UK, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Introduce a National Reforestation Scheme: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/573066

Require developers felling trees to fund reforestation projects: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/578554

attributes.action: Make David Attenborough a Lord
attributes.background: Recommend to H. M. the Queen that David Attenborough be created a Lord because of his lifelong service to nature and education.
attributes.additional_details: David Attenborough has been a constant for generations, educating young and old about the natural world and most recently about the dangers and effects of climate change. He has done more than any other person in the world to bring the wonders of nature into our homes via the medium of television. His spectacular programmes are always complemented by his own unique, beautiful narration. His service to the education of the UK, and wider world, deserves the highest recognition.

attributes.action: Launch an enquiry into the awful free school meal parcels being sent to families
attributes.background: The free school meal parcels being supplied to the needy are inhumane and despicable, and someone is profiting from this. We demand that our government investigates who approved this procurement and holds those to account both in the government and private sector.
attributes.additional_details:
We demand that you:

- Investigate who signed off on the companies supplying the food parcels.
- What the nature of their relationship is, and if there is any corruption.
- Make public the total costs paid for these contracts, including costs spent on the food parcels vs their actual value. 
- Hold any parties responsible for profiteering from this process to account. 

It's clear that someone is profiting from this whole mess, at the taxpayers expense and that of the poor. Fix it.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petition:

Hold an inquiry into contracts providing relief food packages
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569756

attributes.action: Stop work on HS2 immediately and hold a new vote to repeal the legislation
attributes.background: We ask Parliament to repeal the High Speed Rail Bills, 2016 and 2019, as MPs voted on misleading environmental, financial and timetable information provided by the Dept. of Transport and HS2 Ltd. It fails to address the conditions of the Paris Accord as costs have risen from £56bn to over £100bn.
attributes.additional_details: Our environment and economy are in peril. HS2 is destroying nature and inflicting suffering on businesses and property owners. Government is investing in an inept and recklessly run project, offering poor value for money. HS2 will not reach Net Zero by 2050 nor help us level up the North. The pandemic has changed how we work forever and invalidated the business case. Given the climate emergencies we face, and now the economic and pandemic crises - Parliament must vote to repeal the legislation.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/314520

attributes.action: Vote for natural herd immunity to take place with support for the vulnerable.
attributes.background: To put it to the people through a vote to stop lockdowns and to go ahead and let the population get natural herd immunity. With this being said steps need to be put into place to keep those who are high risk safe i.e grants available to them so they can isolate.
attributes.additional_details:
For the government to let the people vote to choose whether they want natural herd immunty to take place rather than lockdowns. 
With this vote the high risk would have the choice to lock themselves down for this grants etc need to be put into place for these people, but it needs to be a choice and not enforced.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/551539

attributes.action: Stop the extraction proposals of Natural Gas in St.Ives, Cornwall.
attributes.background: UK Govt funded extraction of Natural Gas by Total and the St. Ives LNG company will affect the local coastline and be detrimental to the ecology of the surrounding area.  The impact is incalculable and irrevocable.  The lasting effects will damage the natural beauty and fragility for decades.
attributes.additional_details: The extraction of natural gas will unbalance the ecology of the area,  damage wildlife,  damage fauna such as sea grass meadows that are vital in carbon sequestration.  The loss of such habitats will cause an imbalance in the forecast ‘offsetting’ of ecological damage and also does not help the govt image and claims to be carbon neutral by 2050.  The extraction, building infrastructure, storage and transportation all add to the carbon costs as well as damaging the carbon capture capability.

rejection.details: It appears that details of plans for natural gas extraction in St Ives, as set out in your petition, are false. You can read an article about this here: https://www.cornwalllive.com/news/cornwall-news/plans-large-gas-works-coast-4488818

attributes.action: Give courts the power to require a defendant to appear for sentencing
attributes.background: The courts should be given the discretion in cases of serious crime, such as terrorism charges, to require the defendant’s appearance at sentencing hearings. It’s unfair for victims and relatives and a denial of natural justice for defendants not to be present for sentencing.
attributes.additional_details: We believe this is a reasonable consideration for relatives of victims, especially in cases where victim impact statements are read out at sentence hearings, otherwise what is the point? There is a public expectation that defendants should ‘face the music’. Closure for relatives, a wholly proportionate measure when balanced against the seriousness of the offence to insist on the defendant’s appearance. Victims should also be able to see the defendant’s face when sentence is passed down.

attributes.action: Reopen garden centres etc in lockdown. Essential business, promotes well-being,
attributes.background: Add garden centres, nurseries etc to list of essential business permitted to trade during Coronavirus. Many don't have online sale of plants. Allow opening with restrictions, protecting staff and customers, similar to supermarkets. Most of us live within 2 - 5 miles or less, much like supermarkets.
attributes.additional_details: Many garden centres currently risk financial ruin, their busiest trading period over the next 3 months. They make a vital contribution to the nation's care of our natural world and wildlife in particular, promoting plants that attract bees and butterflies, both under serious decline. Gardening, whether we have a garden, a balcony or simply a table, helps us to keep physically and mentally well, both essential during this lockdown. Caring for plants helps us to care for ourselves and each other.

rejection.details:
Since you started your petition the Government has added garden centres and plant nurseries to the list of businesses that are permitted to open: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/further-businesses-and-premises-to-close/further-businesses-and-premises-to-close-guidance

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
 
Find out more and watch the Committee put questions suggested by petitioners to Government Ministers and the Deputy Chief Medical Officer: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/news/145767/committee-question-deputy-chief-medical-officer-and-ministers-on-coronavirus-response/
 
Read letters asking further questions of Government Ministers: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/publications/3/correspondence/

attributes.action: Provide guarantee of Settlement Scheme for EU citizen in need to change passport
attributes.background: The Government must provide a way for transgender people and EU nationals, who renews their passport or change their name or gender, to automatically obtain the Settlement Status if it was granted them before, as there is no guarantee since any passport change needs a new EU S. Scheme application
attributes.additional_details: When a person need to change a passport due to natural expiration or needs to change name or gender on it, the EU Settlement Scheme will ve void and person need to prove to be themselves, and that they lived in the UK again, this will create a barrier especially against transgender people, for who being referenced to their old names is extremely painful, and all of the EU citizen who needs to renew their passport and/or are not willing to take a British citizenship

rejection.details:
The Home Office's guidance, EU Settlement Scheme (interim guidance): Gender identity and sex
markers on documents, states:

"An applicant who has already been granted settled or pre-settled status under the EU Settlement Scheme may inform the Home Office that they have transitioned from one gender to another when they update their identity documentation details using the Update My Details service. An applicant may alternatively inform you that they are transitioning from one gender to another using correspondence."

It does not appear to be the case that a person needs to reapply to the EU Settlement Scheme if they get a new passport, and it is therefore not clear what action you want the Government to take in response to your petition.

attributes.action: Legalise human composting in the UK and make this eco-friendly option available
attributes.background: To give bereaved families an eco-friendly end of life alternative to burial or cremation. The human composting process is a natural process which avoids the use of any chemicals or fuels and results in rich, fertile soil being returned to the family.
attributes.additional_details: Burial and cremation are currently the only funeral options available to bereaved families in the UK. Both of these options are extremely harmful to the environment. Over 75% of families opt for a cremation which is approximately 470,000 cremations a year. Each cremation produces on average 250kgs of carbon dioxide which is released into the atmosphere (that's 115,000 tonnes a year) Burial also has its own list of harmful factors. One being the absorption of harmful chemicals into earth.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/624352

attributes.action: Spend a day without using fossil fuels to prevent climate change
attributes.background: To stop fossil fuel usage in the UK for 1 day every 2 weeks. Fossil fuels are one of the major things contributing to climate change, using these produce greenhouse gases, methane, carbon dioxide and water vapour, increasing their amounts in the atmosphere, making it harder for heat energy to leave.
attributes.additional_details: To help stop climate change and reduce the amount of fossil fuels we release into the atmosphere. To save our planet, including all the animals and nature which are struggling to survive because of humanity. We can do this by walking, or bike-riding to places instead of driving, using less energy at home, eating more plant based products, throwing away less food, stopping factory productions that produce greenhouse gases, forcing them to go green and recycling, reusing and repairing more often.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the use of fossil fuels, but it's not clear exactly what action you want the Government to take. It's not clear if you want the Government to ban the use of all fossil fuels, and fossil fuel-derived products, for one day a fortnight, or do something different.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Protect and Enhance Via Francigena and Nature at UNESCO World City Canterbury
attributes.background: Stop Canterbury City Council allowing Corinthian to destroy the holy agricultural land, spring and pilgrimage path  just outside the City to make place for a giant 4,000 house urban extension and sewage works. Uphold international obligation for sustainability: UN resolution 42/187.
attributes.additional_details: People of all faith and none have had spiritual experiences on this land, which has felt the feet of Pilgrims for over 1,000 years and was where Christianity first came back to Britain.  The birdsong, sunset and open space over the fields have sustained residents over lockdown.  Approaching, the Cathedral takes your breath away.  Grade 1 soil produces more crops and it is a final refuge for Kent wildlife whose habitat has been destroyed by urban sprawl without infrastructure. It belongs to all.

rejection.details:
Urban planning and development decisions are the responsibility of each local authority and in this case would be a decision of Canterbury City Council and not one for the UK Government or Parliament.

Most local authorities have their petitioning platform. You can find out more about how to petition Canterbury City Council via the link below:

https://www.canterbury.gov.uk/consultations-and-petitions/petitions/

attributes.action: Increase the annual ISA allowance for investments within the UK market
attributes.background: The general ISA allowance should remain at £20,000 despite inflation rising. However, a new type of ISA called the UK stocks and shares ISA should be launched with an increased £40,000 annual limit. This ISA only permits investment within UK listed stocks and bonds.
attributes.additional_details: The domestic FTSE 100 index has continuously lagged it's peers in recent years. UK investors and UK pension funds who naturally have a home bias, would likely have seen below average returns in the last few years. Compounding this problem, UK firms are increasingly choosing to list abroad due to better company valuations. This can lead to a negative spiral where more UK investors choose to invest their capital in overseas markets and we loose out on opportunities at home.

attributes.action: Review recent energy strategy to make planning for onshore wind turbines easier
attributes.background: There is an energy crisis and climate emergency now. Onshore wind turbines are cheap, effective and quick to install. Onshore wind linked with Hydrogen storage would be a good way to provide clean green renewable energy 100% of the time quicker than the governments proposed strategy.
attributes.additional_details: Debate the planning legislation with regard to onshore wind to put it on a par with a war footing due to the urgent nature and vulnerability of the climate emergency and energy crisis. Consider permitted development on existing wind turbine sites to permit a blade tip height of 119m. Similarly, planning legislation with regards to wayleaves, easements for   infrastructure and grid connections  with a view to streamline and simplify planning and connections for onshore wind.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

It's not clear if you want the Government to review its energy security strategy, or planning legislation, or both, or make changes to planning legislation, and if the latter what changes you want to be made.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Scale/speed up renewable energy to reduce carbon/costs and increase security
attributes.background: Increase the roll-out of UK renewables, specifically Solar, Wind, Tidal and Green Hydrogen, in order to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels for electricity generation. Also, increase research into increasing available storage capacity for renewable energy. Increase the FIT to encourage PV panels.
attributes.additional_details: In October 2021, Sky News reported that over half of the UK's electricity was produced from natural gas. We are currently on course for a global temperature rise in the next century with devastating consequences. A proportion of UK gas supply comes from Russia, who at the time of writing are on the brink of invading Ukraine. It is imperative that UK takes control of it's own electricity supply from renewable sources which unlike fossil fuels cannot be laid claim to by a particular nation.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see a faster transition to renewable energy, but it's not clear what you want the Government to do to incentivise increased renewable capacity.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Prepare & deliver a strategy for developing and using Tidal energy in the UK: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/598785

Require new large buildings include renewable energy generation: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/600894

Join the Beyond Oil and Gas Alliance and commit to its end date for fossil fuels: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/596001

attributes.action: People post covid infection should be able to be exempt from the vaccination
attributes.background: People post covid infection should have a right for medical exemption from vaccination if they wish to opt out.
attributes.additional_details: Natural immunity post covid infection should be prioritised. People should have a right to have a medical exemption if they have had covid and wasn't hospitalised. Create madical exemption as in the Austria government decided that people post covid infection are not required to vaccinate if they do not want to.

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Exempt NHS workers who have recovered from COVID from vaccination requirements: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/603842

Exempt people who recover from COVID19 (with antibodies) from the vaccine: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/602031

attributes.action: Recognise Natural Immunity from Covid, as equivalent to being Fully Vaccinated.
attributes.background: In line with other countries that recognise natural immunity from prior Covid infection as a legitimate form immunity. I would ask the Government to match the current requirements regarding travel and restrictions to be the same as those who have been fully vaccinated.
attributes.additional_details:
Millions of people in the UK have recovered from Covid and have demonstrated a strong, long lasting immune response, exceeding that of the current generations of vaccines. 

Studies have shown that natural immunity confers greater protection and lower transmission rates than the current vaccines.

A person that can prove their antibody status, through a test, should be afforded the same rights in society as the fully vaccinated. 

https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.08.24.21262415v1

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action:

Recognise immune response to Covid-19 in the Covid pass
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/600576

attributes.action: Stop the introduction of a mandatory covid passport system for Britsh Citizens.
attributes.background: Allow the British public the freedom to make their own choices over personal medical interventions and not victimise those who choose not to be pressurised by the state to be vaccinated. They should make natural immunity testing available to all.
attributes.additional_details: We are supposed to live in a democracy but the British Government has used the pandemic to erode the rights and freedoms of its citizens using emergency measures as their only mandate. I believe that unless this is adressed we, as a country run the risk of slipping silently into a dictatorship where the rights, opinions and views of individuals are no longer considered. It should be the individuals choice to protect themselves by getting vaccinated and not the states.

rejection.details:
You may like to sign the below petition we currently have open on the topic:

Outlaw discrimination against those who do not get a Covid-19 vaccination
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/575801

attributes.action: Reopen public toilets and stop charging
attributes.background: Public toilets are a necessity, not a pleasure. More and more are closing, and those that remain open are charging up to 50p. It’s scandalous and the government should stop this happening
attributes.additional_details: Many people, especially older people are afraid to go out in case they get caught short. Many can’t afford the money required to have a pee, and many don’t have the right change. Going to toilet is a natural and unavoidable thing, just as much as breastfeeding, so why are we being charged ? It’s a disgrace. It’s against the law to pee in a hedge etc. but what other choice have you when faced with a desperate situation. I believe it would bring more people back to the high streets

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for.

Decisions about local toilets are a matter for individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to require local authorities to provide free public toilets, and provide funding for increased numbers of public toilets, if that's what you want to happen.
